reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s decision-theoretic/VNM framework (completeness, continuity, independence) and the permissibility of sharp gamble-style tradeoffs used to define and operationalize ‘value’ and ‘fussiness’. This is fairly central to the paper’s more technical Section 3 argument that most plausible moral views are fussy, but less central to the broader Section 2 narrative claim that many plausible futures have hard-to-notice moral catastrophes; hence moderate centrality. The critique moderately weakens the technical apparatus by noting that many moral theories (and approaches to moral uncertainty) reject VNM/independence and may not license the paper’s quantitative comparisons, but it doesn’t show that the paper’s conclusions cannot be recast in alternative formalisms, nor does it engage the paper’s own caveats about representability; hence moderate strength. Most claims are correct (these axioms and the implied tradeoff structure are indeed controversial), though it somewhat overstates the extent to which the core ‘eutopia is hard’ thesis is merely an artifact rather than partly supported by independent, non-formal considerations. It is clear, focused, and contains little filler.
title: VNM decision-theoretic assumptions may artificially inflate apparent moral fussiness
